div.head: TO THE MOST HIGH AND MIGHTIE KING, IAMES, BY THE GRCE of God King of Great Brittaine, France and Ireland, &c.
div.p:
LONG doubting most mightie Prince, either to passe my griefe in silence most safe with Pythagoras, or to hazard speech in danger with Calisthenes, sith Demosthenes got as many Talents by not speaking, as Isocrates had by speaking, And therefore J must rather striue more with vertue then accuse fortune, though more vnfortunate then he that cryed in Aistophanes, that he had beene more then a thousand times vnfortunate,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . that J may weepe more with Heraclitus then laugh with Democritus,
and the rather that Bias escaped the fire at Prienna, Socrates the bullets at Tanagra, & Zeno shipwrak on seas: my selfe so vnfortunate that I sinke and suffer piracie on drie ground, with no lesse cause to sob then the Great Alexander had to sigh, He for want of children, and I for losse of my children. Whē Pindarus had asked himself 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , who was great then in Greece, not Aristotles happy man, not the Stoickes wise man, nor stout Achilles in Homer, but they which had store of Owles in their houses in Athens, and they that had Snailes put vp in their chests in Sparta: for then virtus & sapientia testudini cessit, and so it is in all places, that he that hath not a friēd in court, if he write as many books as Chrysippus wrot Oracles, he shall he considered as Crates
the Theban laide downe in his Ephimerides, Triobulum Philosopho, sumū Consiliario.

Hauing therfore most noble Prince spent my time sub Aegide Palladis scaling Pythagoras letter vntill age, sicknes and pouertie, haue summoned me to yeld my weapons Principi & Paenatibus patriae & to liue now like poore Lamachus & Antisthenes cum pera & baculo, and as Hippias the poore Philosopher learned in his olde age to make socks & slippers: so my self in the like age, learned to make glasses and spectacles: which if J might sell them as deere as I bought them, poore Irus should be as rich as Craesus, and he that liued sometime in face of the Sunne in Court, should not now liue as one of Menippus Moates in the moone out of the Court.

J hope I shall see through my glasse
some honorable friend that will commend my Spectacle to your Maiestie, and to accept them as naked Gymnosophists in their Indian coats, but better glasse then that Athenedorus gaue to the Caesars in Rome, or that Simandius commended to the Pharaos of Aegipt, but of late Simon Magus had his glasses abroad placed in Cyclops heades, and thought to d • as Alexadner did of the moneth Iune in Macedonia, so to make the moneth of Nouember in England to be the merry moneth of May in Rome, some watching secretly vnseene with Giges ring for honor and dignite, some ready with Mydas hand for the spoyle, and many of them expected for the fift of Nouember in England should be like the Jdes of March in Rome. They looke that day to haue
their full triumphes, and to put vp their Trophese: but vnus idemque dies alter & albus: for that happened to king Iames in England as happened to Mardocheus in Persea, to Moses in Egipt: and to Lucculus in Rome: for periedes of kingdomes are limited of God not to be destroyed but by the sinnes of Kings and kingdomes: let vs then for the fift of August, for the fift of Nouember in coronatis conuiuiis coronati canere poean. Longing to heare the murther of Coesar in the Senate, and to heare Brutus cry liberty out of the Senate.
Let vs that scapt their Kalenders, their Nones, their Ides, their moneths and their yeares, sacros cannere himnos. So did the Hebrues sing phaesah in Aegypt and the Jewes sang Phurim in Persia.

div.head: Linceus Spectacle.
div.p:
THe children of Israel beeing bitten by serpents in the wildernesse,
• . Reg. 1 • . complained to Moses; The brasen serpent. And God cōmanded Moses to set vp a brasen serpent, that by looking on that serpent, they might be healed & helped from the other serpēts.

Cities also were appointed of refuge,Ioshua. • 0. for poore offenders, as sanctuaries to rest vntill their offences were further knowne, not for such as Ioab and Adonias, who were taken from their Sanctuaries, their Temples, and from the Aultar.
Neither for such as ranne to Cinna or Marius, to subuert their countrey, but as hospitals, appointed for such as by chaunce or against their will had offended.3. Reg. cap. • .

Hence grew the custome with Pagans, Alex. ab Ales. that soldiours that so offended, fled either to the sepulchre of Theseus in Athens, or to the tombe of Achisles at Sygaeum, so might poore seruants that were iniured by their Maisters, flie to the Statues and the Images of dead Emperours and Kings.

It was a kinde of lawfull Appeale in all Iudea, to
fly to the highest court of Synadrion, and from all places in Greece, Amphictions. to appeale to the Court of the Amphictions, in that kinde of order Paule did appeale from Festus to Caesar.

Many poore Courtiers, whose glasses are broken, would willing appeale if they knew where, but to the Court is the best appeale, for there was one with Augustus Maecenas, which fauoured learning and learned men, one Endimelech in that wicked court of Zedechias, that helped poore Ieremie from his dirty prison,3. Reg. 13. and there was one Obadiah in that Idolatrous court of Achab, that fed the poore hungry Prophets of God, beeing in want euen in Egipt, there was one Ioseph to comfort Israel.

Courtiers must wrestle with fortune, & striue with vertue, hic labor hoc opus est, they may not excuse themselues, and say my fortune is too weake to contend with fortune, and my vertue no vertue to striue with vertue, and to say impare congressus Achilli.

But if the Courteors had beene as warie, and carefull as the Bee is by labouring in the Summer against winter,Plin. lib. 10. cap 69. prouiding in youth for age; in building their houses, in prouiding their victuals, & as the historie saith, politiae student & regi seruiunt, they should finde no fault but in themselues.

So is it written of the silke wormes,Rhod. lib. 9. cap. 38 of the Locusts, and of the little Ants, that haue more prouident and naturall care of themselues, then Man
hath, as Plutarch doth write of them in his booke De solertia animalium.
O quanta infaelicitas fuisse faelices, how vnhappy is it to haue beene happie, it is better sometime to be poore with Aristides in Athens, then to be rich with Crassus in Rome.

So Themistocles wrote from Persia to his friends in Greece, perijssem nisi perijssem, it is therfore all one to laugh with Democritus at any kinde of fortune, as to weepe with Heraclitus, there is no trust in Fortunes friendship, and therefore tried friends are easily numbred.
Miletus beeing asked,Miletus. why he could not number aboue fiue, answered, I can number well, when I can number all my friends.

The Thracians, The Thracians that could not number aboue foure or fiue, like Miletus, beeing asked, why they were not taught to number more, answered, to number our foes were infinite, which no Arithmetick can teach, to number so many friends in Thracia is much, and so it is in other places. Many had bin happy, if they had not bin happy, many had beene wise, if they had not beene welthy, & so might Cresus haue said, had Cresus thought on Solons saying.

But this kinde of happinesse is like Ionas gourd,Ionas gourde, Ionas. 4. which groweth in one night, and perisheth the next, like that flourishing greene baye tree, which flourished for a short time, and decayed at a moment, At sors certior, e celo.

Elias buckets are euer full and readie to wet the3. Reg. cap. 17.
barren ground of the godly Courtiers,Elizeusoyle. Elizeus oyle is alwaies present to fil all the empty vessels of the poore that cry to God, their glasses are euer running.
And therefore let poore Courtiers be as resolute and ready to laugh at any hard fortune, with Democritus, Democritus. as to weepe at any misfortune, with Heraclitus.

Let poore Courtiers wrestle with fortune, and striue with vertue, though farre vnable by fortune, to contend with fortune, and far weaker in vertue to striue with vertue: Rare is that vertue which is not gouern'd by fortune; and most rare is that fortune which will be ruled by vertue, Rara virtus quam non fortuna gubernat. It is in Kings and Princes so to doe, posse, and velle: for Caesar beeing admonished, that hee should not leade his Legions to Africa before winter,Caesars saying. did answere, as Lucullus sometime did, beeing forbidden to leade his Armie into Armenia: For that they were Atri dies, I will said Caesar, Atros illos dies, albos facere, with the like words answered Lucullus, and so Kings and Princes may doe.

So the greate Alexander, being perswaded by the Macedonians: that the whole moneth of Iune, was an vnfortunat moneth for the Macedonians to fight in,Pla • . de leg. 1. Alexanders saying. I will then, saide Alexander, make the whole moneth of Iune, the moneth of May, but he that ouercommeth himselfe, saith Plato, ouercommeth all things, which is more then Caesar, or Alexander
could do, qui se vincit, vincit omnia.

Aristippus being asked to what purpose do men bring vp their children in learning, answered,Rhod. lib. 16. Cap. 13. that when they come to sit on Theaters, to see games & playes, ne lapis super lapidem sederet, that one stone should not sit vpon another, and that they might through Linceus spectacles see faults.

The like taunt,Laert. lib. 2. Socrates gaue to one of his schollers, who had his picture well painted on a stone, and said, thou hast beene very carefull to make a stone like thy selfe, but be as carefull (said Socrates) that thy selfe bee not like a stone,Psalme. 115. for so the Prophet saieth, of such as make Images, and Idolls, Similes sunt statuis & Idolis quae faciunt, that they are like the Images and Idols which they make.

O how many men, were then in Athens, and in Roome, like stones, and how many more now and then in Spaine, I wish they were not in great Brittaine which do offer, giue & bestow, more money vppon such dead blocks or stones, then vpon the seruants of God in Church, Court, or Cuntry.

Many cry in Kings Courts of Demosthenes sicknes called Angina. A sicknes proper to Orators,Angina, the sicknes of Orators. yet a number of naturall Orators, though not brought vp in Vniuersities, that knowe the difference betweene Logique and Rethoricke, cum apertis & clausis manibus which haue mel in ore, & verba lactis.
This sicknes must be healed with Demostenes medicine out of Harpalus purse silendo non loquendo

Some are sick in Court of Argentina, Argentina the sicknesse of Lawiers a sicknes that followeth Lawiers, much like to the kings Euell, which cannot be healed without the Kings hand on it, or Midas finger touch it, all must bee gold that they handle.

And there is another kinde of sicknes in Court called Argentantina, Argentantina. of which sicknesse the Phisitians cannot heale themselues with Antimonium or Mithridat, though it be a kings medicine, but they most seeke out Anulum gigis who while they weare that ring on their fingers, they shall be healed of any sicknesse whatsoeuer: Then they may write as Menecrates did to Philip of Macedon, for they are more proude for making one whole, then sorry for killing a thousand.

But if these sick Flatterers in Courts, were opened by Chyrurgions, many should be found to haue heary hearts,Rhod. lib. 11. cap. 40. as Aristomenes hart was found in Athens: And some other hearts (being opened) should be found full of thornes, as Harmonigenes heart was found in Sparta, and some should be found like Lu, Enobarba in Rome that should not only haue brasen beardes, but also Iron faces and leaden hearts.

Cunning flatterers must haue in Court two faces,Flattering Glasse. as Ianus had, and as many foreheads as Cecrops had. And I doubt very much, as many hearts as the Partriges of Paphlagonia, of which Theophrastus writeth, and yet litle enough to please all humors in Courts, yet in their flattering glasse
they shall see much, and more then in any glasse else besides.
And therefore these kinde of flatterers may be well compared to Quadrigemina Porta a gate in Rome, where some such flatterers, at any time might enter in, and goe out at pleasure.

But the poore lame Cripple could flatter none of the Iewes in thirtie eight yeeres,Ioan. 5. although he lay hard by the Poole Bethseda, to help him into Bethseda: Northe poore blinde man that cried to Christ, Thou sonne of Dauid, could haue one to speake to Christ for him, but all bade him hould his peace, none of those company that then followed,Iob. 29. might say with Iob Oculus fui caeco pes claudo & pater pauperum. Of all such flatterers Alexander Seuerus the Emperour would often say, that Hanibal might passe more easily, through the hard Rocks of the Alpes into Italy, then Truth, in tanta Adulatorum turba to the eares of Kings in Courts, so rare a vertue is Truth in Courts, that the glasse of truth is soonest broken in Courts, Aristippus glasse is more vsed in Courts then Solons glasse.

No glasse in Kings Courts hath beene more noysome, well proued in all Histories,Aristippu • Glasse. then the glasse of flatterers, placida loquentes, praua struentes: for sweete and pleasing speech, with Aristippus in Courts, are more accepted, then true or profitable speech with Solon.

And therefore these flatterers are like to Penelopes Geese, of which she dreamed that they came to
her Hall to peake her wheat in the absence of Vlisses or rather like the foule Stymphalides,
• . Reg. cap. ••
which came to the Arcadians to deuoure their corne: yea they might be likened to Belus Priests which made their bellies Caemiterium ciborum, and made Nabucadnezar beleeue that God Belus eate vp all his meate, and dranke out all the wine.

But Vlisses draue all Penelopes geese out of Ithaca, Penelopes geese Vlisses draue. Hercules slue all the rauening Harpies that deuoured the corne in Arcadia, and Daniel chokt God Belus and slue all his flattering priests.

Diogenes being asked what kinde of wilde beast were worst, saide, that in the mountaines, Lyons and Beares; in Cities, Sycophants and Flatterers: and againe being asked what is the most daungerous beast vpon the earth, among wilde beasts, a Tyrant; among tame beastes, a flatterer.

The Popes Calender, the Turkes Alcoran, and much of the Iewes Talmuds: the first furnished with Legions of lies, the second with Turkish fables, the third like proud Pythagorians 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . All three so full of flatterie that the Popes foote must be kist, Dyonisius Turkish heeles must be spoken vnto, and the proud Rabbins will not be contraried.
There wanted no flatterers in Court with Absalon, Hatterers follow Courts. against the King his Father, nor with Adonias against his brother Salomon.

Balaac King of Moab was not so well pleased with Balaam, to praise Israel so much, though Balaam
they spake truth as God cōmanded him, neither did Balaam honour Balaac as he did before, Cum placenta sibi verba dixisset, that also was the cause that Achab hated Micheas the Prophet for telling truth: for had Micheas flattered Achab, as the false Prophet did Zedechias, and say with Zedechias, 2. Paral p. 18. His Syriam ventilabis, donec deleas eam, Micheas had not not bin put in prison, & fed with bread and water, & the cause why Zacharias was stoned to death, was for telling truth to the King and his Nobles.
Miserable is that Court, where truth may not be spokē, Verum silere, aurum sepelire est, truth must lead the way to him that saith Ego sum via veritas et vita.
What infected Salomon? flatterous women,3. Reg. 11. Amonites, Moabites, Sydonites: Pharaos daughter.

And would haue infected Moses, Exod. 2. had not Moses fled from Egipt, where hee was adopted sonne to Thermutis daughter, and heire to King Pharao, and maried to King Tharbis daughter, & heir of Aethiopia, left both the kingdomes due vnto him, and fled from such idolatrous nations with his glasse vnbroken, and vnstained.

And as Abraham was commanded to depart frō Vr, among the Chaldeans:Genes. 12. and appointed the first father and preacher of the faith; So was Moses appointed to be the generall captaine, & deliuerer of his people Israel. Let the cleane be kept from the vncleane.

div.head: The glasse of Trauellers.
div.p: THe glasse of Trauellers, after they had consumed their time in diuerse kingdoms and countries, to learne languages, & to see fashions and maners of diuerse Nations: Then home with the prodigall Sonne, they returne to their country, loaden with strange sights and wonders in greate pouertie.

One commeth from Scythia: where he saw black snow,Hielfild. cap. 10. de aquis. ye must beleeue him, if Anaxagoras say so; another from Armenia, where he saw red snow, another from some Yles in Persia, where trees beare woole, and other trees beare gourdes.
Some come from Cypres, where they saw brasse sowed like corne in the earth, and growne like brasse out of the earth.

Some saw where vines bring forth candida folia ex puro auro, Strange sights of trauellers. white branches, and leaues of pure gold, caried as great presents to Princes and to Kings, and yet they could carie not a leafe, nor a braunch home with them: to shew such wonders in their countrie, to their friends, to be short, they saw with their eies more then Plinie wrote with his pen, and yet left no monument behind them, as Plinie did.
But if Trauelers had seene what they might haue read:Exod. 14. They should haue seene greater wonders.

Where Moses walked in the bottome of the sea,
where Elias was carried in a fiery charriot into the Ayre: for so Chrisostome cals Moises, 2. Chron. cap. •
viatorum in mare, et Elias aurigam in Aere, no doubt Sathan was amazd to see Elias in a fierie charriot,The Diu • ll is the great traueller. drawne with fierie horses in his region, he is the onely traueller in the aire, in the seas, in the earth.

So a great rich man at his death told his friends that he was willing to die, but that hee feared theeues which lay in ambush in the middle region among the clouds for him, that is, that great thiefe that was cast downe from heauen with millians of theeues with him.

Againe where Enoch was taken vp aliue in his bodie into heauen. Farre greater wonders then to trauell to see where Vulcan fell from heauen to earth in the Ile of Lēnos:Vulcan fell frō the heauens to Lemnos. where Vulcan was so crushed by his fall, that hee euer after went lame. That Cicero called him Claudum deum. Homor Ilia. 10. Homer saith that a whole day was Vulcan in falling downe to the earth from heauen.

One of the maisters of Israel a great Rabbin of the Iewes,Ieron. in Daniel. hearing that Abbacuck was caried by the haires of the head from Ierusalem to Babilon with a messe of pottake in his hand to Daniel being in prison with the Lyons, made but a scoffe of it.Ezech. cap. 5.

And againe hearing that Ezechiel in like sort was caried from Caldea into Iudea, Derisit hominem, & tooke it for fables, and thought it more wonderfull and straunge then to heare Pismiers to bee as bigge as Elephants,Lucian Vat. hist. 1. or the foot-steps of Hercules
and Bacchus to be as bigge as an acre of ground.

Some Philosophers also haue trauelled as Pythagoras to the priests of Memphis: Old Philosophers treat trauellers. Apollouius trauailed to Persia, to see and to heare their Philosophers, and their Magi, from thence to Scythia, to the Massegits, and to the Indians, to heare and to see Hiarcas sitting in suo aureo throno, Hiarchas. reading Astrologie to the Brachmans.

Plato vt qui magister erat Athenis, Plato. hee that was Maister in Athens, trauelled from Greece to Egipt to become a Scholler, to learne and to augment his knowledge to profit his Country, these and many others trauelled to Ethiop, & to all parts of the world, to see Tantalus well, to heare Gymnosophists, Gymnosophists and to see the golden table of the Sonne in Sabulo Ethiopiae.

But of all good and great trauellers, Paule the Apostle, Magister gentium, better taught and instructed to teach others, then all these philosophers:Paule. After he had trauelled to Arabia, to Damascus, and to all kingdomes and countrys, to teach Christ, both to the Iewes and to the Gentiles, he trauelled further to the third heauens, where hee saw more wonders then were seene in Sir Thomas Moores Vtopia. He trauels well that striues to the narrow way, to that rich India where that welth is most sure & safe (said Antistenes) that can in Shipwrack swim through seas to land,Laert. de vita Pi •• ol. that can frō fire scape free frō burning, & frō Bullets, scape Battering, so Zeno escaped shipwrack, and caried all his
wealth with him, so Socrates escaped the bullets at Tanagra, and Bias the fire at Prienna, so that each of them three might say one sentence, Omnia mea mecum porto.
So can not the Marchant say, though hee brag much of many ships vpon the seas,Cic. Tus. quest. lib. 5. yet as the philosopher said, sua f •• icitas è funibus pēdet, his wealth hangeth on cables.
So cannot the rich couetous Niggard say, which possessed his wealth, quasi suis vinctus catenis, and maketh hast to be rich, when in truth ad vltimum nil, nisi lenta faelicitas.

For if fortune and vertue bee ioyned together, and waighed together in Critolaus ballance, it shall be found as Critolaus did, who waighed bona animi, et bona corporis in one ballance,Cic. de finit. and found the one like stellae in radio solis, the other quasi sol ipse splendore virtutis.

So it may be said of the Ambitious that builds towers in the aire, whose nature is more agreeued to see one man go before him, then reioyce in a thousand that followe him,Esth. 3.4. one Mardocheus troubled Hamans minde more then all Persia could please.
Some great men ambitious among the Iewes,Num. 16. tooke vp Moses and Aaron, saying you extend too much of your selues, ye Sons of Leui, Cur cleuamini super populum Domini,

For that they were the best Tribe amongst the Israelites, but such God euer raised and furnished
with wisedome and vertue, to be stars and pillers of his people in his Church.

The Greeks hauing diuerse such ambitious men in euery Citie of Greece, Aristoph. in Ramis. Aristophanes brought in a commaedie Pericles from hell, to admonish the Atheneans, non oportere leonem in vrbe nutriri, yong Lions must not be nourished in Athens, and therefore great rich & noblemen must be bridled, from hauing too much honour and power, lest thereby,Solons lawes. they bring Solons lawes to Dracas lawes.

The like we reade that Priamus Deiphobus, and many other Greeks and Troians were brought in vpon a stage, vgly, g • astly, and bloudy to perswade men that liue ill, to liue better by the terrible and horrible sights of such great men, beeing dead, & in hell punished, Exempla magis mouent quam verba, and therefore I wish such were plaid on their stages in London, and not such wanton lassiuious &c, I wish it were before Kings in Courts.

The rich man in hell,The rich man in hell. requested Abraham, to send one from the dead to tell his brethren the tormts and paines he was in, and though it was told him by Abraham, that they had Moses & the prophets to instruct them, but that was nothing to be beleeued in respect of the other.

Yet many trauel to Africa, Diodor. 2. to seeke out the Ile of Satyrs, and become Satyrs thereby, many trauels into Arabia, Satyrs. to seeke out the Ile of Serpents and become Serpents thereby, and many trany trauels to all parts of the world to seeke out
purgatorie, and are become papists thereby, each of these haue their glasse in their hands, to finde their way and yet misse it.

div.head: The glasse of Hunters.
div.p: TIrus a Greeke Author in describing the natures of diuerse nations,Athenians. in warres the Athenians to be sea souldiers,Lacedemoniās the Lacedaemonians, land foot souldiers, the Thessalonians horse men. And for that the people of Creete are most giuen to hunting, and hunting much resembling warres: For the cry of hounds are as sweete musicke in Creete, as the cry of souldiers in Assiria: For if the crie of souldiers were altogether consonant and agreeable,The cry of soldiers and the cry of hunters must be alike. ad primum congressum cum hoste, the Assirians were animated, and assured by the couragious crie of the Soulers to haue victorie, but if they were dissonant and not agreeable, the Assirians doubted of some faint-hearted souldiers:Songs of warre and sacrifices. for it was the onely cause why Cyrus willed his souldiers after sacrifice done to Castor and Pollux, to sing warlike songs, with loud instruments, lest they should bee terrified with the horrible cry and clamor of the enemy.

So the Lacaedemonians not with trumpets, as the Romans, nor with drums, kettles, pots, and pans, as the Parthians did, but with flutes and soft
sweete musicall instruments sing martiall songs, and dancing in their armours.Ioshua.

So was the commandement of Ioshua to his soldiers after they had gone seuen times about the wals of leticho,Iericho. to sound the Rams hornes, and to shout with a lond crie. And Gedeon to his souldiers willed them to breake their pitcher pots, and to make a sudden Ioud crie,Iud. 7. and so to set on the enemies, saying, Gladius Dei, & Gedi • nis.

So the hunters iudge of their games by the consent and dissent of the crie of their hounds: For by the dissent of the crie,The Ethiopian souldier. they resemble the Ethiopian souidiers, who withall dissonant crie, and horrible houldings enter the battell.
So the old Gauies with raging and furious clamors without order set on the enemy.The old Gauls.

So some vnskilfull hunters, that cannot recall their hounds, being at Counter, that knowe nor how to put them to the right sent againe, no more then an vnexpert Captaine can vpon the like disorder, know to instruct his souldiers.

Well therefore is hunting compared to warres, and the hunters to souldiers. It should seeme that Alexander the great loued hunting well,Alexander. Diodor. lib. 17, Biblioth. who gaue King Porus a Kingdome for a hundreth and fiftie Indian dogges: For Alexander brought nothing out of India but dogges and Elephants: For Alexander left many of his souldiers in India.

Haniball also loued hunting:Hamball. For he hunted seuenteene yeares in Italy for Romes sake: For by
hunting Haniball got Tarentum and Capua.

Mithridates a great hunter,Mithridates a great hunter. who for forty yeares kept wars with the Romans, vsed hunting for chiefe exercise in wars: For the cry of his hounds was as sweete to King Mithridates in Asia, as the neighing of a horse to Darius in Persia, the one saued himselfe (by hunting) from the Romains, the other by the neighing of a horse, became King in Persia.

The loue of dogs,The louée of dogges. compared with the loue of men, it is probable, that some dogs lept into the flame of fire to be burned with their Maisters, some haue dyed on the graues of their dead Maisters, & some haue drowned themselues, with swimming after their Maisters.

Therefore the old Romans couered their household and country Gods, with dogs skinnes,The old Romans. trimd and deckt with sundry, and diuerse kinds of Garlands, made with sweete flowres & franckensence, and placed them in their gates, porches and gallaries, to watch and guard their houses from theeues and robbers.

In the Temples of Minerua in Achaia, The Temples of Minerua & Iuno. Alex. ab Alex. lib. 1. cap. 3. and in the Temple of Iuno in Samos, dogs were kept with better trust to be watches, and guards of their Tēples, then men: for feare of Sacriledge.

Masinissa, King of Numidia, had dogs for his guard, to watch in the next chamber to his Bedchamber, such was Masinissas trust to dogs,val. Max. lib. 9. cap. 13. though he had 54 Sonnes, and a large kingdome, all the
Romans his deere friends: yet esteemed more the biting and barking of dogs before all.

It would be tedious to write examples of Dogs,The loue of Dogs to their Maisters. for Cymon the great Captaine of Athens, had a dog that loued him so well, that he dyed in prison with his M. Zantippus as great a Captaine as hee in Sparta had a dog that loued him so well, that hee swam after his Mr. from Sparta to Salamina, where the Dog dyed for wearines, and his M. buried him.

In Africa, a dog was worshiped, and had in such reuerence, that they did gouerne and rule their common weale,In Africa Dogs worshiped. by the motion and gesture of a common weale, by the motion and gesture of a dog, so did they in Ethiopia, prognosticate and cōiecture things to come by their dogs, euen in the like manner, as the Arabians and the people of Caria, by flights of foules, and the Romans by lyuers of beasts.

But to conclude, dogs were so esteemed in kingdomes and countries,Osyris. that Osyris the great King of Egypt displayed a dog in his chiefe Ensigne in wars and the Emperour Heliogabolus was caried in his Triumphs, by soure great dogs.

div.head: The glasse of Soldiers.
div.p: THe crie of the valiant soldior,The bragge of Souldiers that he was in as many set battels as Marcellus, which was in 39 battels, in as many combats as M. Seruilius, which was in 23 combats, & in as many victories as Caesar himselfe, which wan 52 victories.

This soldier cryeth, that he serued such great Captaines, which were most famous, and though they come lame and maihemed home, yet it doth them good to remember the victory in besieging such a Citie, and of their fighting on the seas in such a place, there escaping of the bullets,Eneas sang to his Souldiers. that it doth sollace the Soldier to cry with Eneas, haec olim meminisse iuuabit.

You must not take from the souldier his valiant mind, his martiall actions and exployts in warres, for the souldier will bragge as his Captaine: for as Nabucadnezar sayd, What God can take Sidrak, Esa. 14. Mysael and Abednego out of my hand, so Rabsases his Captaine will say, What God will or shall defend any kingdome from his maister.
And as Demetrius spake to Ionathan, Learne,Demetrius. 1. Macab. 3. and know of others who I am, Quia mecum virtus bellorum est.

The souldiers of Benhadad will say as he sayd, that the dust of Samaria is not enough for euery soldier of Benhadad to take a handfull;3. Reg. 20. For if the gods of the mountaines will not fight with him, the gods of the valleyes shall.
Another Captaine crieth out like Seron against Iu. Machabeus, saying, Faciam mihi nomen, I will get me a name on Iudas Machabeus.

Another like Gaal with the like proude crie,proud bragges. What is Abimelek, and what is Sichem, O I would I had some such soldiers with me at my command. So Pyrrhus wisht and Marius would haue Romane
souldiers, Non calones, non iactatores, take away the brag of a souldiers seruice, take also his reputation and life away.

And therefore amongst the Thracians,The Thracians which brag that Mars was borne in Thracia, their greatest glorie and fame was to haue cuts and wounds on their faces and bodies, thereby to be knowne valiant souldiers.

But amongst the Lacaedemonians it was not so,The Lacedemonians called Comati milites. for their souldiers kemd the long haires of their heads and beards: and therefore they were called Comatimilites, which when the Captaines of Persia saw Leonidas souldiers at Thermopila so deckt and so trimd, Velut desides & ignauos habuerunt, but they iudged otherwise of them before the battell was done: For that 20000 Persians were slaine by 300 Lacaedemonians, who came with sweete slutes and soft pipes.
And the Souldiers therefore in Macedonia sit crowned with Lawrell by the Law of Alexander the Great to see Games and Plaies in the best places and highest roome of the Theatres.Lawrel crowns.
In Persia the souldiors haue golden girdles giuen them by the Law of Cyrus, Golden girdles to animate the soldiors to fight for their countrey.
In Greece they had siluer laces and golden fillets to trim vp the haires of their heads,Siluer laces & golden fillets. and therefore were the Lacedemonian Souldiers called Comati milites.

In Rome the Souldiers haue diuers and sundry
kinds of Crownes, golden Chaines, Bracelets, and Rings, in reward of their Seruice.Chains, bracelets and rings. Some had Crownes for sauing of Cities, made of Ex querna fronde, of Oken bowes. Another sort had Coronam Obsidionalem, made ex illo gramine of that grasse, where the Citie stood, by remoouing of Sieges, or otherwise.

Such a Crowne had Fabius Maximus, Fabius Max. which by delayes wearied Hanniball out of Italie, and saued Rome. The like honour happened to Lu Sicinius in the first African Warres: And the third, to Cneius Atinates, in bello Cimbrico, in the Cimbrian Warres.

In Greece Themistocles had Coronam Oleaginam, Reward and gifts in Greece and a golden Chariot, for the sauing of Greece from the Persians. Milciades for his victory at Marathon had his picture in the Port Pucile: And Dion for sauing Syracusa from Dionysius, had Coronam auream.

But now neither in Persia, in Sparta, in Athens, or in Rome, or elswhere, the Souldiers haue nowe no such siluer Fillets, nor such Bracelets of Gold, no golden Girdles, or any other Militarie rewards for the crie of Souldiers.

Onely of this,Watch words of souldiers. Souldiers may bragge of some watch • word called Tesserae militares, which great Captaines vsed in great Warres, as in Persia, the watch-word of Cyrus, in many battels vsed,Cyrus Watch. word. Caesars watchword. Iupiter belli socius, or of Caesars watch-word, who vsed somtime Faelicitas, sometime Victoria, for that Caesar
was himselfe in fiftie two set battels: and therfore vsed many watch-words, which Caesars Souldiers made great account of, after Caesars time.

Least I should vse too often Tautologia, for that I remember I wrot of Pompey the great,Pompeis glasse broke at pellusum. Plut. in Pomp. for his great victories in Asia, Affricke, and Europe, three parts of the world was cōpared to Alexander the great, whose word was Hercules inuictus, yet his Glasse brake on the sands at pellusium, in Egypt.
Antiochus, Antiochus. surnamed Soter, vsed this for his watchword to his Souldiers in his warres, aduersus Galatas, bene valere.
These many watch-words shall suffice to solace Souldiers in their crie.

So likewise may poore Souldiers weare their great Commaunders and Captains cullors,Ethiopiam soldiers of the cullors of diurse and sundry maner in warres. as the Aethyopian Souldiers weare white cullors, the Thracian Souldiers russet cullors, the Africans puke cullor, the Samnites pied or partie cullors, the Lacedemonians vsed Scarlet cullors, and the Persians red cullors: For such cullors ware great Artaxerxes King of Persia, in field against his brother Cyrus, and Cyrus Souldiers ware white cullors in the selfe same battell against Artaxerxes: Artaxerxes cullor. but the most of these Nations their glasses were bruised and broken at that time.

And so may any Souldier now weare any cullors,Cyrus cull or. if it be but in Ribbands or Laces about their neckes, to remember and to honour valiant and warlike Nations, and to satisfie their owne valiant
and noble minds, and to stop their cries, in steede of deserued rewards.

And yet somewhat more for the honour of soldiers, in whom appeared some naturall grace and Maiestie, to moue people,Plut. in vita. both to loue and honor them aswell in forraigne countryes as their owne,Scipio Emilianus. as Scipio Africanus the elder had such grace with King Antiochus the great, that he ruled more in Asia, then Antiochus & Scip. Emilianus with King Masinissa in Africa, so greatly honoured and beloued, that at his death he gaue the kingdome of Numidia to Scipio.

So Paulus Emilius with the Macedonians, & Pub. Pau. Emilius. Sen. epist. 81. Rutillius though banished from Rome, yet so much esteemed in all the Cities of Asia, that hee seemed rather to make his triumphs in Asia, as the history saith, that Maius Triumphare quam exulare videretur.

Q.Q. Meteilus. Cic • ad Atticum. 1. Metellus could haue no greater honor giuen him by the Senators, then when the table of his creditors were shewed to the Senators that they refused to looke on it saying, non in Tabulis, sed in vita Metelli respiciendum.

The like reuerence and honor was alwaies giuen Marcus Cato that wheresoeuer hee went,M. cato. Gell. 4, cap. 1 • . or whatsoeuer he said in the Sennate house, or to the people abroad, it was esteemed, ac vox cuiusdam numinis, with great admiration.

It is so written o •
Zenocrates, Zenocrates crdit. that when he came as a witnes in a cause before the Iudges Areopagites
in Athens, to lay his hand vppon the altar to take his cath, the Iudges with one voice said, in tanta tanti virisapientia, needs no oath.

C. Marius is not to be forgotten, for that in his seauenth and last consulship in Rome (although an old man,C. Marius Silla and Caesar as great soes as frends to Rome. and in much miserie,) forsaken of all his friends, and left naked without weapons, yet had such Maiestie, then in his countenance, that the Executioner, an enemy of Marius (being a Cymbrian, whose nation Marius much grieued) being sent into a priuat house, close shut, at Minternum, to kill Marius, The grimme countenance of Marius. at the sight of Marius threw downe his weapons and fled, as Marius, Silla, and Caesar were like Scipio to aduance Rome, but againe like Hanibal to plague Rome.

What can be more said then of the greatnesse, and Maiesty of a soldier, yea in the meanest soldier in the field, that though Octauius countenance seemed so great at Actium, yet no greater then M. Perpenna, M. Perpenna. who beeing made a Consul, before hee was a free Citisen, discharged his Consulship, as fullie as though he had gone through all Martiall offices in the field, and did more the Lu. Varro the Cousul at the Battell of Cannes.

Such soldiers were sought for and made much of by Marius & Pyrrhus, Front lib. 3. cap. 1. whose opinion was to haue strong tall men of great stature: that were able to carie their helmets on their heads,Viget. 3. cap. 1. their targets on their armes, their swords on their sides, their peeces on their shoulders, and their viands on their
backes, which to carrie,Cic. Tusc. •• . said Cicero to an olde Romane souldier, was no heauier then to carie humeros, lacertos, manus, &c.

So the old Germanes vsed their souldiers to carie vpon their armours Cibaria ferramenta, and such militarie munitions as were necessary in wars, and as the Romanes then vsed painefull exercise,Apud Salust. Currere laborare & pondus portare, to runne, to labour, to suffer the Sunne in their faces, and the dust in their eyes.
So saith Marius, munditias mulieribus labores conuenire viris.
Among the Greekes it was a prouerbe, Dij bona laboribus vendunt: the gods make sale of labour to men.

Then Rome esteemed Romane souldiers,Valerius Ma • . lib. 4. cap. 1. when Scipio African and such had their Images and Statues set vp in the Capitol, in the Oratorie, and in the Market place, but within a while after, Plus Calonum & scortatorum quam militum, saith Lipsius, followed Romane Captaines.

But as warre to the most part is miserable, so to other some auailable and famous:Herodot. 7. so for a time it was to Xerxes, who gathered all the Princes of Asia to go against the Grecians, told them, that hee sent for them, not to be Xerxes Counsellors, but to obaie Xerxes, Vobis magis parendum quam suadendum est.

Haniball as insolent as Xerxes, Polyb. 3. after his great victories ouer the Romanes at Cannes, admitted no
soldier, no Citizen to come to his tents, neither did he answere any Captaine, or to any man else, but by an interpretor.

The insolencie of Alex: Put. in vita. the great, exceeded far Xerxes or Hanibal, he would be called the Sonne of Iupiter, refused his Macedonians maners & lawes, & would be apparelled in Persian garments, but faelicitas impiorum instar puncti, whose life and felicity, in life is as britle glasse, these be they that thinke their heads touch the skye, and looke so hye, that often they fall downe to a ditch with Thales, Iob. 20. these be they of whom Iob saith, si caput nubis tetigerit, cadit tamen in sterquilinium.
Tamberlane the Scithian,The great Turke. that had the great Turk in a cage, like a dogge vnder his table.
Saphor the Persian King, that had the Romaine Emperour as a block to mount on horseback.Valeranus.

And Sesostris the Egyptian that had foure Kings to draw his Charriot, these made no more of men, then Menippus, who thought men to be moates in the moone, if their glasse had beene cleare, they should haue seene quam vita vitrea semper fortuna suit: these had not Linceus Spectacles on.

Had Marius kept his glasse cleare,Marius glasse, hauing beene seauen times Consul in Rome, hee might haue seene what good he did to Rome in the time of Scipio, and what harme he did to Rome, in the time of Silla.

So might Silla after Marius, so might Caesar after Silla, after much good seruice to Rome, beeing Romans
borne, and not after to harme Rome more then Hanibal a sworne enemy to Rome,Fo • s & friends to Rome. but they wanted Linceus Spectacles.

For these warres were not iust warres, and therfore not necessarie illa pia arma (saith Tacitus) quibus nulla spes nisi in armis, it is the nature of all tygrish Tyrants to reioyce in blood, not waying caelestia nu mina sed terrestria nomina, esteeming not heauenly names, but terrestrial fame,Tyrant, spectacles. & to be called reges mag nireges maximi, et reges regum, great Kings, & Kings of Kings, quorum nomina magis acerba quam diuturna.
These be like swift riuers, which run themselues quickly dry by too much vehement motions, and some such there be like standing pooles which do stinck and putrify for want of motion.

Hard by the Citie Hierapolis, in a valley there is a place called Os plutoniū like Auernus in Cāpania of Poets fained to be thentrāce vnto hell,Eneas siluius. both the places so putrified and so corrupted, that the fouls that flee ouer them, fall downe dead into them, & the water that comes nigh stinkes, vndafluens sordibus terrae inficitur.

The riuer of Hypanis in Scythia, beeing sweete & pure of it selfe,Plin. lib. 7. cap. 2. yet when it toucheth any part of Exampius riuer that is better, it is also by the same infected & made bitter, aliquid mali propter verum malum.

But neither earth, water, nor aire is more infected or corrupted one by another, then one man is
insected by another in qualities, in nature, in religion and in saith, qui tanget picem &c. and therfore good men must depart from the tabernacles of Da than, and Abiran.

And therefore Homer the salt that seasoned all Greece,Homer the salt of Greece. & fild all their stages and Theators, not only with comaedies of the quick, to make men acquainted of the differēce between vertue & vice, but also with Tragedies of the dead to moue terror & feare among men, sometimes brings Vlisses, somtime Pericles, and sometime brings in Agamemnon and Achilles to instruct Greece from daungers to come: by dangers past, renued & plaid vpon their Theaters, as in the glasse of trauell is more mentioned, he had Lynceus Spectacles, and saw the discord of the Grecians before Greece was knowne,Homer properly named Melesigenes. and yet Homer was blinde, so was Iacob, and yet Iacob could foresee, and prophesy the liues, and the succession of the twelue tribes.

div.head: The plowmans glasse.
div.p: THe greatest commanders & Gouernours appointed of God to Iudge Israel as kings, Iudges, Priests and Prophets, were such poore men as Moises, Saule, Dauid and the like, who were heardmen & shepherds.

In such poore men, God was euer pleased, euen from Noah, of whome God said, te iustum vidi, Gen. 7. Abraham a poore man the Sonne of an Image maker, amongst the Chaldeans, whom God so blessed,Gen. 12. and in whose saith and seede, all the elect of God are blessed.
Iacob the Patriarch, went so poore a man ouer Iordan to Mesopotamia, but with pera & baculo, Gen. 28. a staffe in his hand, and a wallet on his back.

These and such like became so great in Gods fauour, that sometimes with such victories, and somtimes with such miracles, that all the Kings of the Earth trembled at the names of these heardmen & shepheards, while they cryed to God, and called on God for helpe, their glasse flourished and continued.

In all Countries, poore and verteous men, were the first founders, and the glory of their countries, as it should seeme both in Athens by the building of their famous Court Ariopagus, Val. Max. lib. 4. cap. 4. couered with straw, at the first, et per humilia tecta Capitolij, et casem Romuli, and by the simple building of Romulus house the capitoll, and by such other poore buildings, that from the plough, poore husbandmen,Plowmen. as Cincinnatus was forced frō the plough to be Cōsul in Rome, and as the history saith, cur cesso nominare bubulcos, called to be Magistrates and officers in Rome, and from the name of the poorest men, the greatest families in Rome descended as Publicolae, fabricij, Scipiones, Emilij, Curij, and other such,Alex. ab Alex. lib. 3. cap. 1 • .
quibus paria robora virtus aluit.

Then poore men were cried for, and meanes made to find out such poore wise men, as were sit to rule and to gouerne, Tunc fuit laudata paupertas, when they made two Temples in Rome,Temples for pouertie made. the one named Templum paupertatis, the other called Templum pietatis.
Then the Emperours of Rome had the Image of Fortune in their Galleries, of glasse, but it was made of such brittle glasse, that still it was broken.

When Iulius Caesar and Mar. Iu. Caesar. Crassus were both at one time Censors in Rome, sweete Oyle and strange and forraine Oyntment were by lawe forbidden in Rome to be sold, the example thereof came frō the Lacedemonians, who banished such daintinesse from Sparta.

Then Epaminondas flourished in Thebes,Plut. in Aristid. more by his pouertie then by his wealth: then Aristides might brag in Athens more of his iustice, then of his money: it so proued true, that at their deaths they were not able to marrie their daughters:Prob. in vita. then Fpaminondas said, Nunc vester Epaminondas nascitur quia sic moritur.
That noble poore man Lamachus being elected to be chiefe Gouernor of Athens,Lamachus. was forced to borrow money of his friendes to buy him such a cloake as was fit for such a place.

It should seeme that pouertie was much accepted in those dayes, both in Rome and in Greece,
when Themistocles wanting money to performe some seruice to the Athenians,Plu. in Themist. tooke two poore Gods with him out of Athens, the God of necessitie and the God of Counsell, and went to the Isle of Andria, either to begge or to borrow some money for those two poore Gods sake, as the Iesuits and Seminaries did sometime in England:Begging Gods. But the Magistrates of Andria answered Themistocles, that they had also the like two Gods in their owne Countrey, the God of pouertie, and the God of Impossibilitie, that did commaund them to the contrary.

But within a while after,Pouertie. poore men were cast off, and reiected both in Rome, in Athens, and in all Greece, when 30000. Archers came with Agesilaus from Persia to Greece,Plut. in Agesil. when the wealth of Asia was brought by Scipio to Rome, thē the Owle in Athens, the Snaile in Sparta, and the Oxe in Rome were turned into Elephants of India.

Then Templum paupertatis & Templum pietatis were remoued from Rome, Tanquam noxia numina, and in their places were builded two rich & stately Temples, Templum honoris, & Templum fortunae: Alex. ab Alex. lib. 3. cap. 11. then began to rule in Rome the like 3. monsters that ruled in Athens, which was Populus, Noctua, & Draco, and so in Rome, Forum, Senatus, & Populus then was nothing but Armes and armed men in Rome.

Then Lu. Equitius fained himselfe to be the sonne of Tib. Gracchus, Oros. 5. cap. 17. requested of the people to be Tribunus
plebis: for which sedition, though C. Marius in his sixt Consulship committed him to prison,Appian. Ciui. 1. and Metellus then Censor told the people, that Tib. Gracchus had but three sonnes, the one in Sardinia a souldior in pay, the other a young youth, then brought vp in Praeneste, and the third dyed in Rome.

Yet the people brake the prison,Marius and Metellus. furiously rushed in, and tooke Equitium vpon their shoulders, and threatened the Censor Metellus to death, & made Marius the Consull to be quiet for that time.

M. Drusus in the like rage dealt with L. Philippus then Confull in Rome, Drusus being but Tribune of the people,L. Flor. lib. 3. cap. 17. Tribunus Plebis, drewe him violently into prison, and being sent for by the Senatours, to come before them into the Senate, answered, the Senatours should rather come before mee in my Courts in Hostilia, and Rostro, so Drusus esteemed not the state of the Senate, and the Senators obeied the words of Drusus: Tribunus despexit Senatum, Senatus paruit Tribuno: Nihil tam inaequale quam aequalitas: for as wealth and pouertie are two contraries, yet are they two necessaries: for the one is so made for the other, that one cannot be without another.Aug. de verb. diu serm. 25. Pauperis est errare, diuitis est erogare, Dei est vtros{que} pensare.
What equality was then in Antigonidas a poore Musician, to say, Cane mihi & Musis, as well as Themistocles, Cane mihi & Marti. Many thinke too well of themselues, that their glasse cannot lōg endure.

As Alcestides a Tragicall Poet taunted Euripides, for that he was three dayes in making three verses,Valer. Max. lib. 3. cap. 7. sithence my selfe (said Alcestides) haue made three hundred Verses in three dayes, Euripides answered him, and said, Tui tantum in triduum sunt mei autem in omne tempus, Thy three hundred Verses are but for three dayes, mine are for all times.
Like the Foxe that obiected to the Lion,Gell. lib. 13. ca. 7 that he brought but one whelpe at once, and I bring many: yea, said the Lionesse, but that one shall be a Lion which I beare.
But it is otherwise with all men, Nunc cygnus qui modo coruus erat.

But to returne againe to the poore mans glasse,Flor. lib. 2. ca. 28 which excuse themselues, saying, Necessitie hath no law, sometime truly spoken: but what necessitie had the poore souldiors at besieging of Numantia by Scipio, Iamnies. to fill their bosomes with dead mens flesh, to liue like beastes, when they might die like men, beeing by Scipio offered martiall pardon, like the Iamnites, who were found with their Idols and Images in their bosomes, after they were slaine.

Or at the siege of the Caliguritans by Pompey the great in Spaine,Oros. 5. cap. 25. after all their beasts and horses were slaine to satisfie hunger, after to kill their wiues and children being aliue, to shew their loue and fidelitie to Sertorius their Generall beeing dead. These made more of their glasses, thē of their
wiues, or of their children.

Rich men are alwaies in necessitie,Kich men are alwaies in necessitie. & haue great need of money, for they want what they haue, yet not ynough, though they haue too much, althogh they haue more then doth them good, vnlesse they make such friends of wicked Mammon, as Daniel counselled Nabuchadnezzar to giue almes, and to feed poore mens cries, or as Zacheus said to Christ, Halfe my wealth and substance I giue to the poor, but some of them will receiue with two handes, but haue not one to giue,Moloches Chemarius. like the Priestes of Moloch, called Chemarims, euer reaching hands to take.

Septimelius, Cie. de Orat. a couetous Romane, slew his familiar friend Caius Gracchus, and carried his head through Rome on a poule to Opimius the Confull, who promised any man that would bring him Crassus head,Septime lius promise. the weight of Crassus head in golde, Septimelius therefore melted Lead into Gracchus head, to make it the more heauie, to get the more gold thereby.
So Cyrus head, & so Crassus head, the one drownd in blood, and the other fild with melted gold.

Amongst these couetous Captaines Ptolome gouernor of Cypres,Valer. Max. lib. 9. cap. 5. most ranck with thē in the first front, who perceiuing his ship to be full fraughted with gold and siluer, and his soldiers in great danger to perish,A most wicked man. made meanes to get his gold and siluer to Cypres, and after caused the ship and all the soldiers to be sunck, to defraude them of their
pay and booties, of such doth Iob say,Iob 20. diuitias quas deuorarunt euomuerint.

But these greedy Captaines will answere as Dionisius the Tyrant of Syracusa, who beeing accused of a Philosopher, that he spoyled and robbed, not onely men, but also committed sacriledge against the Gods, said merrily,Cic. de na • . d • or. lib. 3. I tooke Aesculapius Golden beard, because his father Apollo had none, I tooke Iupiters golden cloake, because it was too cold in winter, and put a cloth cloake on Iupiter to keepe him warme.
And as for golden crownes and golden basons,Elian de va. Hist. lib. 1. which the Gods seemed with reaching forth their hands saying, Accepi non Auferrebam.

So many like Dyonisius, will take poore mens houses ouer their heads, and their lands, & sometimes their liues to get their lands, and will answer scoffingly as Dyonisius did, so that the poore haue euery where cause to crie on such as Dyonisius was.

Many like Achab that so sought the poore Prophet Elias, 3. Reg. 19. that Elias was weary of his life for feare of Iezabel, and yet Elias could command fire and water from Heauen, the one to burne Achabs soldiers, the other to wet the earth with raine,4. Reg. cap. 2. which had beene long dry and barren for want of rayne.

In the old Testament, the most part of the Patriarks were poore heardmen and shepbeards: In the new Testament, the most part of the Apostles were poore fisher men, whose cryes was alwaies
hard, and whose request was graunted to do wonders and miracles. Tunc illa viguit pia paupertas.

And so the first poore men in Rome were sent for,Plin. 18. cap. 3. Cic. pro. Ross. some from plowing, some from sowing, and some from such like husbādries, that At. Regulus was sent to the first African war in Carthage, Q. Cincinnatus sent for to be Conful in Rome,Liui. 3. & M. Scaurus to be a Dictator of all the Romane Armies, so that these poore men, qui vastissimas glebas cum sudore pessundabant, that from their goades, their yoakes, and their oxen became to be generalls, Consuls, and Dictaters in Rome. tunc fuit illalaeta paupertas.

div.head: The gratefull glasse.
div.p: THe Prophet reprehending the vngratefull Iewes, to be more forgetfull of their God then Brasse, for the oxe knoweth his Masters crib, and the Asse knoweth his Maisters stable.

The Scripture is full of such vngratefull examples, Ioseph that by his great wisedome saued all Aegipt from famine and diuerse plagues, how soone did Egypt not only forget the name and posteritie of Ioseph, but also requited the good deserts of Ioseph, Exod. 12. vpon his children, and childrens childrē, with killing and drowning, that the Egiptians became such Tyrants to Israel, as Israel was vngratefull to God.

Many giue faire words and promise much:Exod. 12. but they performe as little, as Pharaos Butler did to Ioseph, and yet I would that some would doe as much, for he after long imprisonment of Ioseph by Putiphar told Pharao what Ioseph did for him when he was in prison with Ioseph.

Often Leapers which Christ healed,Luck. 17. Leapers. A Caueat to vngratefulnes. there came but one to giue thankes vnto Christ, yet Christ asked for the other nine, a caueat to such vngratefull men, as forget good turnes.
In Africa, there are many huge monsters, and in India many strange beasts, I may well so call vngratefull men beasts, for that the Prophet cals thē worse then beasts, to be vngratefull men.

The Macedonians esteemed vngratefull men, of most vnnaturall people to forget the benefits of friends,Vngratitude most hated in Athens, and in Persia. against whome they haue actions by the lawes of Macedon, and so thought they in Athens, those vnworthy to liue, that liued against the lawe of nature, to haue one hand to take, as Demosthenes said, and not an other to giue.

Amongst the Persians, vngratefull men should not scape free from punishment, nor yet without markes or notes of infamy, if they were found to be vngratefull, and vnmindful to requite the benefits of their friends.

And therefore the Lacedemonia • s had a Temple in the midst of their market place,The thrace Graces. where the Images of the three graces were set vp to put vngratefull men in memory, of requitall with thankes.

The first had a Rose in her band, to signify the sweetnesse of benefits, the second held a braunch of myrrh, to signifie how thankfull men should be for benefits done, and the third signified that it should endure and continue among friends, and that thereby they might not excuse their vngratitude, for that the law of nature saith, qui accipit beneficium, debitor maneat.

But in such popular state of common wealth, where common people rule and gouerne, there is alwaies some contentions and diuisions, as in the time of Samuel, who whē he iudged Israel well and wisely, yet the people would haue a King, & hauing a good King, yet vpon any disliking, and diuision, some followed Dauid the good King,2. Reg. cap. 19. Sheba the Traytor. and some followed Sheba the Traytor.

Who might doe more in Greece then Dionisius the Tyrant,Scipios thanks banishment. or more in Rome then Catiline the rebell: but Scipio, that well deserued of Rome, and saued Rome from Africans and Carthaginians, and hunted Haniball out of Italy to Carthage, had no other thankes but banishment.

Furius Camillus, named Vindex Romanae Maiestatis, who had bin fiue times Dictator in Rome, and saued Rome so many times,Fu. Camillus. yet could he not be saued in Rome, that vngratefull Citie to such gratefull men: And so might Scipio African, the latter, after he had subdued Carthage and Numantia, he found in Rome,Murther. Murtherers not found. yea, in his owne house Raptorem mortis inuenit, mortis punitorem non reperit, the murther
was found, but not the murtherer.

So the like ingratitude was as well in Greece as in Rome: for who was euer borne amongst the Lacedemonians so syncere, so gratefull, and so louing to his Countrey, as Lycurgus, Plut. in Lycur. of whom Apollo doubted, whether Lycurgus was e • numero Deorum vel hominum, for his great loue and good lawes in Sparta, yet banished from Sparta.
So Solon for the like lawes in Athens, enioyed the like fortune as Licurgus. in Solon.
And so Theseus, the first sounder and Law setter in Athens, the reuenger, and onely Champion of the Athenians, was put to exile out of Athens.

What should I say of Phocion, surnamed the good, for his good seruice to his Countrey,Iustin. 2. and of Aristides for his iustice in his Countrey, surnamed Iustus, yet might they not be buried in their countrey, so vngratefull was Greece to Greekes.Plut. in vita Plut. in vita. Themist.

If it were asked where these great Victors and Conquerors in the battels of Marathon, Salamina, and Artemisium were buried, that defended Greece from ruine and often destructions, it may be well answered, that Theseus bones lie in a little rocke, in the Isle Scyros, Themistocles in Magnesia, a city in Persia, Milciades at Athens in prisō, his valiant & noble son Cymon had his fathers patrimony Carcerem & catenas: the rest of these noble & valiant captains, Cum dispersis cineribus, into sundry places, being banished, were buried out of Greece

All these might haue said of vngratefull Greece as Scipio and others spake of vngratefull Rome:The saying of Scipio. O ingrata patria, non habets ossa mea: for Rome was neuer gratefull to Romanes, nor Greece to Grecians, but all other Kingdomes and Countries most gratefull and liberall.

So Attalus King of Asia found the Romanes liberall,Plin. lib. 33. for that the Romans gaue all the kingdome of Asia to Attalus, and Attalus againe at his death bequeathed all Asia vnto the Romanes by his Will.

In this I know not which to commend: Masinissa, King of Numidia, who (for the like loue and liberalitie of Scipio & of the Romans) did as king Attalus at his death,Plin. lib. 33. cap 11. hauing 54 sonnes, deliuered the kingdome of Numidia to the full power & authority of Scipio Emylianus.

Sylosontis, Gouernour of Samus, who hauing but one most rich cloak,Herodot. lib. 3 whom Darius (as yet a priuate man) much commended, which Sylosontis most liberally gaue to Darius, for the which Darius rewarded Sylosontis both with the towne, and whole Ile of Samos.Elian. hist. 4.

But in this most vngratefull age,Ios. 6. neither loue, benefits, nor seruice is recompenced, how carefull then was Iosua to requite the benefits of the harlot Rahab, in hiding the Hebrew souldiers from the King of Ierico, how ready was Iethro the Madianite,Exod. 2. to recōpence Moses that defended his daughters from the shepheards, and made their cattle to drinke, to make Moses sit at his table, and giue his
daughter Zophora in mariage to Moyses.

Euen that wicked King Saule spared Cyneus life,Saule. 1. Reg. cap. 15. Luk. 7 because hee loued the children of Israel, and the Elders of Israel spake to Christ for the Centurion, saying, diligit gentem nostram: And euery where Paule gaue thankes to God and to men, for benefits receiued of God and men.Gal. 4
An vngratefull man is not worthy to liue among men, And (as I said before) actions in Athens, and in Macedonia, and in Persia, punishment.

In Rome,Actions in Athens, in Macedonia, and in Persia. an vngratefull man being bound and made free, if he would not be gratefull to the Patrone, the Master, or to the friend that made him free, they might bring him into the Court, and say, Quia liber esse nescis, cibi esto seruus, & shold lose his Freedome.

Among the Romanes,The lawe in Rome. if any Citizen of Rome had three children well brought vp in vertue and learning, to serue their Countrey, if their parents were poore and bondmen, they should haue their liberty and be made free in Rome.

Among the Persians their Law was like the Romanes,The Persians. that the father of such children should be relieued with annuall pentions,Law against vngrateful men and that the kings of Persia are bound to giue a piece of gold to euery woman with child, in euery towne or citywhere the Kings of Persia ride through.

Among the Lacedemonians, if any poore man had foure children brought vp in military discipline according to Lycurgus law,the Lacedemomans. the father should
haue immunitie from Taxes and Subsidies, and be made free from all militarie charge.
Then was Pouertie releeued, Artes nourished, Learning esteemed, and Vertue flourished as they say in vacua Simonidis as ca. The liberality of Alexander and Traian.

When Alexander made as many youths in Persia, to bee instructed in the Greeke tongue and in militarie discipline, as the Emperour Traian did in Rome, and in all Italie at his owne charge caused 5000 youths to be instructed in all knowledge and learning, for the vse and profit of their Countrey.
When Cyrus instructed Croesus by his owne example,Cyrus instructions to Croesus. that those friends whom he made rich, Cyrus thought them to be his iewels and chiefe treasures in store.
Then Caesar said, that he had enriched himselfe when hee had done good,The saying of Caesar. aut officijs, vel beneficijs.

Then Artaxerxes accepted a dishfull of water at poore Sinaetes hand,Artaxerxes liberalitie •
out of the Riuer Syrus, for Cyrus sake, with the reward of 1000 Persian coyne of siluer.

Then was learning and learned men esteemed,Cic. pro Archia when Scipio African caused the Image of Enneus to be made in honorem Corneliae gentis, when Pompey the Great gaue to Theophanes for a small deale of writing, in aduancing Pompeyes greatnes, a whole Citie.

What should I name the great Alexander, Cic. in Bruto. Cic. Tuskit. Plut. in vita. Cic. pro Arch. that gaue 800 Talents to Aristotle, for writing of one Booke De Natura animalium, which Alexander was as well able to giue, as Aristotle worthy to receiue.
When D. Brutus so esteemed few verses of Actius the Poet,Cic. Tusc. that he caused them to be set vp in aditu templorum, to honour Actius verses, as well as to aduance thereby his owne fame.

And yet in these our daies, meaner men would be so praised, without any liberalitie, Qui suas effigies cum Phidia in Clipeo Mineruae includerent, not as Themistocles, being asked,The answerē of Themistocles. whom he would haue to set foorth his noble victories and worthie prayse? euen he (said Themistocles) that can best aduaunce any name and fame,Many like the Fox would be a lyon by craft, & many would be made great. A quo artes me canentur optimae.
But Antigenidas, who wouldelayme Themistocles prowesse and fame by Musicke.

Let some men write as many bookes as Chrysippus wrot Oracles, vnlesse some such Mecaenas were in Court, as was with Augustus the Emperor, they should bee rewarded but as Crates the Theban hath set downe in his Ephemerides, Triobulum Philosopho, fumum Consiliario, Flatterers well rewarded. for bookes are mortui & muti magistri, to induce any gratitude: And yet in the selfe same Ephemerides, Decem Talenta adulatori.

In Courts flattery is eloquence,Flattery is Eloquence. and such eloquence as Pisistratus vsed to the Athenians, that if
Solon had not contraried his eloquence, Pisistratu •
had brought the Athenians from liberty to seruitude,
〈◊〉 . 10. lib. 1 at which time an old man in Athens said, Let all men beware of Pisistratus eloquence,An old mans saying. which in Courts is flattery, Lubrica via & vita in Aula versantis.

In the time that Pub. Volumnius was Consull in Rome,plin. lib. 2. cap. 56. Plinie writes, that infinit pieces of flesh fell from the clouds vpon the earth, like as the Quailes that • ell to the murmuring Iewes in the wildernes: of which, the people gathered some, the sowles of the ayre deuoured some, and some remayned on the earth for certaine daies, without euill smell, or colour altered.

I thinke now otherwise,Diogenes answere to a question. that as the Prophet then threatened, that the heauens should be turned into brasse, & the earth to yron, Coelum anneum & terra ferrea, where no liberality, no gratitude, nor thanks scant giuen, that if it were demaunded, as one did to Diogenes, on whom should good turnes & benefits be bestowed, it might bee answered as Diogenes did, not to children, for that they would forget to requite benefits when they were men: not to olde mē, for that they might die before they did requite benefits: nor to poore men, for that they will neuer be able to requite benefits: nor to any man, but to such as can presently regratifie you.Cic. de opt. gen

It was not so in Athens, for he that should do good to his countrey, or be any was beneficial, that man should be crowned with two Oliue branches, to animate
others to vertuous exployts, vberimū virtutis alimentum honos, so was Pericles the first man crowned in Athens, by the lawe of the Iudges Areopagits, which long continued after Pericles in Athens for such as Pericles was, that Athens was gouerned by his directions and Consuls 40 years.

Many in Courts can giue good counsell,3. Reg. 22 and few can take it, King Zedechias & his nobles, might haue taken counsell of Ieremie, Achab might haue taken counsell of the Prophet Elias, of Micheas, as well as of Zedechias, and of 400 other false flattering Prophets: but their flattering glasses were all broken at the brooke Kyson.

Their wanted neuer a number of flatterers in Courts, that would honesta at{que} inhonesta aequè Laudare, Tacit. 3. anui. wayting and tending hard in Court to haue time to whisper in Princes and nobles mens eares,Ad Q. Fratrem Cacit t. an. qui insusurrantin aures Principum, as Cicero saith.
Of such Tiberius the Emperour said, they should take great care in Court,The councell of Tiberius. to shunne chiefly two things, danger and shame, ab optimis periculum, apessimis dedecus.

The flint stone is harde, and it was cut in two, Actius Rasor, nouacula Neuei, the Adamant is harder,Actius 〈◊〉 . and yet disolued Sanguine hirci, and are the harts of men harder then flint and Adamant, that cannot be mollified Sanguine Christi, the stone of Sion, of which the Prophet saith, Ego fundamentum posui in Sion lapidem, this is the stone that we must build vpon, this is lapis angularis, which the builders reiected,
and this is that great mountaine, quem Deus contriuit in puluerem mortis, Dan. 2.4.5. which Daniel saw in his vision, he is that stone which Barnard speaketh of, cie quo sonat tinitus pietatis, et ebullit oleum charitatis,

Iob biddeth man aske the beasts what God hath done for man,Iob. 1.2. How more thankfull all creatures are to God then man. and the beasts shall teach you, and aske the foules of the aire, and they shall tell you, Speake to the earth and it shall shew you, or the fish of the sea, and they shall declare vnto you how vngratefull man is to God for all his goodnesse to man, and where man to man should be so gratefull that it might be said, homo homini Deus, and not as is euery where seene and proued, homo homini daemon.

And therefore the crie of all creatures of the world is vpon Man: for that man is vnthankfull to God,The cry of all creatures vpon man. for the which the heauens cry out and saie, I giue thee light in the day, to walke & to see what thou dost, & I giue thee darknesse at night, to take thy rest and sleepe, and therefore accipe beneficium.

The Ayre cryeth out on man,The Aire. and saith, vitalem tibi praebeo to liue, and to take thy breath, and all kinde of foules to feede thee,The water. the water cryeth out and saith, I serue thee with all kinde of fish: for thy vse to eate.

The earth cryeth out on man,The earth. and saith, I bare thee first in my bellie, and now I beare thee on my back, and I feede thee with bread, wine, and with all kinde of flesh and fruits, and therfore redde debitum beneficium.

Consider man of the crie of these creatures,The cry of heauen. the crie of Heauen, of the earth, of the water,Hugo lib. cap. 3 de arca. of the aire, and of the fire, is but vox famulantis, the voice of seruants.

The second cry is vox admonentis, The cry of the world. the cry of the world to man, and saith to man, remember man how much God loued thee, quipropter te, fecit me, to serue man, that man might serue God.
The third cry is vox comburentis, The cry of fire. the cry of fire to man, A me combureris, thou man shalt be burned of me, the water cryeth to man A mesubmergeris, in me man, thou shalt be drowned.
The earth and hell cry, A nobis deglutieris, The cry of hell thou man shalt be swallowed and drowned of vs, & ther fore Iudge supplicium.

div.head: The Bloody glasse.
div.p: NOw to the cry of blood, which is the greatest and lowdest crie: for that it is hard out of earth into heuen, for God testified so himselfe frō the bloud of Abel, who did Edere clamorem ad coelum, that ascended vp to heauen to complaine against Caine, and from the blood of Abel to the bloud of Zacharia the priest, sanguis edit clamorem.

The blood of Stephen the first Martyr, cryed to heauen for Iustice against the wicked Iewes: for this sinne is so hatefull to God, that though God
loued Dauid well, yet God for bad Dauid to build him a temple,Dauid quia vir sanguinis fuit, because Dauid was a man of bloud.
I haue in my bookes of consent of time, and Stratagems of Ierusalem and the histories of the Iewes & Romans, sufficiently proued with examples for that mouent magis exempla quam verba.

And therefore Christ himselfe crieth out with a watch word vnto vs, vigilate & orate for that foules in the ayre, and stones in the street will bewraye bloud: Augustine also notes some kinde of men in whom there is nothing but Cupiditas nocendicrudelitas vlciscendi. Aug. lib. 22. cap. 74.

If Craesus the only wealthie man of Rome had beene so contented, or by Actius Tribune of the people perswaded to stay better as a Consull of Rome then rashly to go to the Parthians where he heard a voice of on which cryed figges of Caunea, which as the historie saieth,Terrible voices. prognosticated his death in Parthia, such a voice hearde Amilcar.

The voice and crie of bloud was heard in Ierusalem Migremus hinc a while before the destuction of the Cittie,Ioseph. lib. 7. cap. 12. & againe another voice before that time, Vae ciuitati vae & populo.

This crie was more terrible in Hierusalem then the crie of the Romane Centurian in Rome Hic manebimus optime which stayed all the citizens of Rome in Rome,A crie in Ierusalem. & would haue fled for feare of the Gaules, to Veios.

The cry and voice of Samuels shadow to Phaetonissa at Endor, that Saule should die Gilboa, 3. Reg. 21. this voice was as sweete to Saule, as the voice of Elias to Achab, that dogs should lick his bloud in Israel, in theselse same place, where dogges lickt Naboths blood.

The cry of a voice, to Augustus the Emperour at his last going out of Rome was,The voice of Augustus. that he should neuer returne againe to Rome, which was as sweete to Augustus, as the voice hard of Nero de Mauselo, that the Senators made hast to send executioners to kill Nero, or to bring him aliue againe into Rome, but he preuented both, kild himselfe.
These voices of the cry of blood, are more terrible then the roaring of Lions, of Tigers,The voice of blood. and of Elephants in Theatrall hunting in their games of Circenses at Rome.

Ye more terrible then the Egyptian stratagem to the Scythians, who perceiuing the Scythian souldiers to be the best horsemen,An Egiptian stratagem. though in Egipt they cānot abide an Asse, yet for necessitie sake, they got a number of Asses together, whose cry so terrified the Scythian horses, that they made as great hast to returne from Epypt to Scythia,Scynthian Horses. as the Ammorites did from Gabaon, when hailstones and great stones slue them in theirflight to Bethoron, this was a cry of blood from heauen vpon the Ammorites, Bethoron. to reuenge Israel: and this cry is from the bloud of Abel, to the bloud of Zacharias the priest.

The Scythian historie much agreeable to this,
that when they came to Persia, stayed longer then they did in Egypt,The answere of the Scythians to Datius. and beeing sent vnto by Darius to know when they would make an end of their marching and stand in battell to fight, they answered, cum adsepulchra venirent parentum, Darius should know that they came with a cry of bloud to reuenge Scythian bloud, vpon their fathers tomb so God doth limite time to be the Iudge and arbitrator of all controuersies, lex talionis, bloud for bloud.

So God reuenged the Tyrannie of Adonisebech, Adonisebech. Iud. 1. who had seauentie Kings vnder his table, fed with the crums that fell vnder his table, without fingers to their hands, and without toes to their feete.
The like tyranny vsed Abimelech a Iudge in Israel,Iud. 9. who kild 70 brethren at one time, in one place, and vpon one stone, Turcorum Tyrannis,

div.head: The Tyrants and Ʋsurers Glasse.
div.p: POets faine,Vsurers are monsters. that Briarius was such a monster, that he had a hundred hands, and fifty bellies, but there be some more monstrous, that haue more then a 100 hands to rob and to spoyle the poore, and more then fifty bellies, to eate & deuoure the poore, I meane the monstrous vsurers.

These be the moathes that eate mens clothes off their backs. These be the Canibals,Vsurers the Moathes, Cannibals, and Caterpillers. which M. Cato whipt out of Sicilia. These bee the Caterpillers which Lucullus banished out of Asia:

These be the rauening Harpeies that deuoures mens corne yet on the ground, which Lu. Genutius exiled from Rome: And these bee they, whose bread in their bellies shall be turned into Serpents gaule. So Iob sayth, Panis in vtero vertetur in fel aspidum. Iob. 20.

For it was lawfull in Rome before this time for Vsurers, for want of payment, to vse their Creditors, as men vse their wiues:Alex. ab Alex. lib. 1. cap. 7. So Caelius Plotius a great Vsurer in Rome would Constuprare Ti. Viturium, and so Papyrius would Pelicere Publium ad libidinem, for not making satisfaction of his debt to the Vsurer, O seculum Daemoniorum, for men to vse men with buggerie.

Archimedes was named amongst the Greekes Hecatonchera, Plut. in Marcello. for that he could shoot at one shoot a hundred bullets: These bullets of Archimedes was as terrible to the Romanes in Syracusa, as Dionisius tyrannie was in Greece, or Tarquines pride was in Rome, and yet all these io • ned together, are not so terrible as tyrannicall Vsurie.

There was a barbarous Nation in Scythia called Anthropophagi, that feede on mens flesh,Tyrants and vsurers. now dispersed to diuers Kingdomes and Countries vnder diuers names, as Tyrants, Vsurers, and bloudy massacres.

Yet in Egypt the Glasse of Vsurers was much accepted and allowed by Law:Vsurie allowed in Egypt. for the Vsurers in Egypt might arrest the body of the Creditor before he should be buried: which was the greatest infamie that could be in Egypt.

Yet by the Law of Senatus Consultus in Rome, that which by the Lawe of the twelue Tables in Greece,Alex. ab Alexandro. lib. 1. cap. 7. Vsurers that did vse pro arbitrio faenerari, were bridled for their accesse in Vsurie, as by the selfe said Lawes are set downe, De modo credendi per Senatus consultum.

In Athens of long time,Agis Vsurers made too great excesse of vngodly gaine, vntill Agis time, duke of Athens,Vsurers tables of debts burned at Athens. who burned all their Tables of Debts in the Market place; and called Vsurers Tyrannos.

In Sparta Lycurgus made a Law,Vsurers banished. to banish Vsurers out of the confines of Lacedemonia, so odious and hatefull a name was Vsurie,Vsurets compared to African monsters. that the name of an Vsurer and the name of a Tyrant were all one, and was more monstrous in many countries then those monsters which Plinie writes to bee in Africa, some with heads like dogges, some with long eares to their feete, and some without eyther head, or eare, but with one great eye in the middest of their breastes, like Polyphemus the Cyclop.

But as Plato sayth of Vertue, It Vertue might be seene,Platoes saying. it would make all men much enamored with it; and so of these monsters, it would
terrifie any man to looke vpon them, if their inward foulenesse might be seene outwardly.

Heraclitus a Philosopher of Ephesus was willed to make some speech concerning loue and concord amongst the people,Heracliitus stratagem. beeing much molested and troubled by two great enemies, Vsurers and Tyrants: the Philosopher to satisfie the request of the people, went vp to the Pulpit, and called for a dish of cold water, and a little meale on a trencher, which the Philosopher put into the dish of water, mingled together, and dranke it vp, and came downe from the Pulpit without any more words.

Some of his friendes most desirous to knowe what he meant therby, answered,Thrasibulus stratagem. Herodot. lib. 7 Torquatus Sextus knew his fathers meaning, and Periander knewe Thrasibulus minde, when the one did with his staffe Percutere capita papauerum, and the other, in detruncatione spicarum.

These dumbe stratagemes of mine did signifie the like, that Sextus should eyther banish the greatest men of the Gabians,Periander. or should take off their heads, and so Periander to doe the like execution vpon the Nobles of Cotinth.

So that nothing can call Tyrants from their Tyranny, but punishments,2 Mach. 9. Anticchus that cruell Tyrant, after that God had plagued him for his Tyranny in Ierusalem promised and vowed to repaire the Temple,Antiochus promise. and to recompence the harme and euill that he did to the poore Iewes, se aequales Iudieos
Atheniensibus facturum.
