So did Heliodorus vow and promise to the High priest (after he was whipt and scourged by a greater Captane then himselfe,Wicked vowes. for his robbing of the Temple) amendment of his Tyranny, which was greater good workes then such Tyrants could performe.

Such trecherous vowes told Absolon to the King his father Vadam et reddam vota mea, 2. Reg. 15. Act. 23. the like vowe made the Iewes to the High priest, Nihil gustaturos, before they would kill Paule.

Such vowes and sacrifices the Prophet reprehendeth, for that they were bloody, cruell, & Tyrant like, and of such the Lord saith, I delight not in your vowes and sacrifices, quia manus vestrae plenae sunt sanguine.

The difference betweene Kings and Tirants is,The difference betweene kings and tyrants. that the King holdeth his sword in his hand, in munimentum pacis, the Tyrant vt timore magno, magna compescat odia, Seneca. saith Seneca, and therefore the life of a Tyrant is short & execrable, for his bloody glasse can not long endure.

For Thales the Philosopher beeing asked what was the strangest sight he had seene,Thales saying. answered, Tyrannem senem: Iob. 20. For if a Tyrant scape Seylla, hee falleth into Charibdis, fugiens arma ferrea irruet in arcū aereum.

All Tyrants thinke and say as Dionisius the elder saide to his sonne, that Armed men are the surest friends for Tyrants to trust vnto, at which Plato
smiled, & asked what euill Tyrants doe, they must be so guarded,The saying of a Philosopher of a Tyrant. so it should bee said an other Philosopher, that Tyrants should be, muniti gladijs, et septi venenis, to keep them from doing harme to others, for Tyrants are alwaies armed to doe euill, they say licet si libet.

Antigonus was of an other minde then Dionisius was, & said that faithfull friends,Antigonus. saying. the loue & good will of subiects, are a stronger band then Dionisius band, and therefore Kings ought to make much of their Subiects,Arist. lib. 8. polit cap. 10. to loue and to haue care ouer them Rex subditorum commoda quaerit, Tirannus sua.

It is most necessarie that they which feare not god shold be punished of God, & therfore was Isra el afflicted by Pharao in Egypt,Israelits afflicted. bitten in the wildernesse by Serpents, murthered and slaine in their Countries by many Tyrants, dispersed and scattered to all parts of the world, vntill they knew the Lord.

So Manasses confessed,Paralip. 34. Manasses. Iudith. 23. after much bloud and tyrannie in Hierusalem, & so Nabuchadnezzar acknowledged God, to be God, whē he was cast out from amongst men, to be as a beast among beasts, who thought before to subdue the whole world, vt solus diceretur Deus.

The swallowing of Dathan and Abiron, Num. 16. with the rest of their complices, quicke to the earth, was to put the people in feare, thereby to feare God: the Trumpets, the smoking and quaking of Mount Sion, was to terrifie the Iewes (said Moises) ne peccarent
in Dominum.

The poore scattering and dispersed Iewes in Persia,Assuerus. the Lord appointed one Mardocheus to looke vnto them, that Assuerus the great king of Persia, that said to Haman, Doe with the Iewes what thou wilt, as Zedechias King of Iuda said to his Nobles, Do with Ieremie what you please.

And to the poore Hebrewes in Egypt,Pharaoh. vnder that cruell Tyrant Pharaoh, God left one Ioseph to comfort Israel, one Moses to deliuer Israel, and one Ioshua to fight for Israel, that neyther Assuerus in Persia, nor Pharaoh in Egypt, could vex the people of God, no more, nor no longer, then God suffered.

But as these bloudie Tyrants delighted much in bloud,bloudy Tyrants so the crie of bloud followed them to their graue. And so of these wicked Vsurers, that as the Tyrants were neuer satisfied with bloud, so they are neuer satisfied with money.

That some of the Iewes were so oppressed by the rich Vsurers in Iudah,Nehe. 5. that they were forced to satisfie these Vsurers with the sales of their sonnes and of their daughters, to be their vassales and seruants,The tyrannie of vsurers. vntill Nehemias beeing then in great fauour with the King of Persia, rebuked them, and shamefully reprooued them for their abhominable Vsurie.

For before the Law Sisactheia was made against Tyrants and Vsurers,The law of the 12 Tables. it was lawfull (as I said before) by the Lawe of the twelue Tables to satisfie themselues with cutting in pieces of the dead
bodies, and so to be paied of their debts by pieces of dead mens flesh.

But few doe foenerari domino, which is vaileable Vsurie, and great gaine, to gaine Sextuplum & centuplum, and not such gaine,Simon Magua. as Symon Magus the Sorcerer, to offer money to the Apostles, that vpō whomsoeuer hee should lay his hands, might receiue the Holy Ghost, to gaine money thereby: Nor with Ananias and Saphira his wife, to make a lye to the Apostle, and to keepe backe the money which should haue beene confest to Peter. Not with such couetous men, as wish Mydas hand, that whatsoeuer they touch, should be gold:Giges ring. nor with ambitious men, to wish Giges ringe, that whatsoeuer they say or doe, should bee magnified by the people.

This is not foenerari Domino, this is not to make friends of wicked Mammon, to giue almes to the poore, to feede the hungry, and to clothe the naked, this is not to relieue the fatherlesse,Esai. 1. the oppressed, and defend the cause of the widdow.

But these ambitious Tyrants haue nothing in their hearts and mouths, but vtinam, so Gaal said, Vtinam populus iste esset sub manu mea, so ambitious Pyrrhus spake of the Romanes, so ambitious Haman spake of the poore Iewes in Persia.Pyrrhus.

Thus they by wishing and speaking, climbe from one rotten bough to another, as Augustine sayth, Per pericula ad periculum grandius, till the rotten
bough bee broken, and then their ambitious glasse is broken.

The ambitious Tyrant as the base Gorse,Hest. 3. which would be King amongst the Trees, like Abimelech; and yet one Mardocheus or other is alwaies in their sight, that troubleth them: Like that prowd and ambitious Haman obtained of King Asuerus, Esther. 3.5. Omnem nerem Iudaeerum, for one Iewes sake to reuenge his malice vpon all the poore scattered Iewes through all Persia.

Mithridates of meere spight to the Romans caused all the poore Romanes,Mithridates. dispersed throughout all Asia, to the number of 80000 to bee slaine in one day, for the hatred hee had to Lucullus and Pompey, Quivna Epistola 80000 Romanorum ciuium intremito.

For crueltie and tyrannie,Val. Max. lib. 9 cap 2. the Thracians, a Nation to whom no crueltie seemeth cruell to sawe quick men in the middest, to make the parents eat their owne children, a nation, cut nihil esse nephas putarunt, not their most cruell King Numulizinthes might not in Tyrannie match Pto. Phiscon. of whō Iosephus make mention.

Who caused his only sonne to be slaine before his face,Lib. Antiq. 2 his head to be cut of, both his hands and both his feete in like sorte eut off, and send it in a rich chest couered to his mother Cleapatra, and his wife, as the historie saith, pro munere natalitio matri misit.

To what end should I recite the Tyranny of Ochus,
surnamed Artaxerxes, Euseb. 〈◊〉 12. who buried Ocham his sister and his mother in lawe aliue, who slue an hundred more of his childrens children, Cum centum filijs ac nepotibus iaculis cōsixit: for that they were well beloued and much exteemed in Persia, the only cause of their destruction, vt hijs trucidatis tutius regnaret.

Yet all the Tyrants of all Tyrants of the world, nor all the pollicie and inuention of man, Epeus wooden horse to destroy the stout Troians,Archimedes. Cic. in pis. Perillus brasen Bull, to destroy the Agrigentins, nor all the Mathematicals inuention of Archimedes to destroy the Romans, could not come nigh to that diuellish stratagem at Westminster.

div.head: The glasse of Images.
div.p: ONe thing of the cry of Gods, and of Images, to shew forth some superstitions.Cic. 2. de natura. de or. Vatinius a Roman Citisen, walking in an euening out of Rome, met with Castor and Pollux that cryed to Vatinius and said, that King Persius was taken, and all his Macedonian Armies called Phalanges slaine.

Mars himselfe was also seene taking the Romains parts against the Brutians, and Lucanians,Val. max. lib. 1. cap. 8. at the battell of Thurina, where Mars snacht a Roman Ensigne, and cryed aloud to the Romans, to followe him, who rusht before them, through the midst of
their enemies, when Phab. Lucius was Consul.

Againe beasts also spake in Rome, which is most strange, that a dog spake in the time of Tarquine the proud, and another time a serpent did barke, or the lowing of an Oxe, should be turned to the voice of a man, when Pub. volumnius was Consull in Rome.

Yet why should not Oxen speake in Rome,Oxen spake in Rome. aswell as Oules in Athens, for as Bos in Lingua was in euery mans mouth in Rome, so Noctua Athenis, was in euery mans mouth at Athens, so that Oxen in Rome, and Owles in Athens spake all, and did all,Oules in Athens. without which, nothing could be done, nor nothing could bee heard in Rome, or in Athens.

During the time of the Peloponesian warres,Plut. in lisando. which continued seauen and twentie yeares: Snailes ruled & gouerned the most part of Greece, that it was as common a speach amongst the Lace demonians, virtus et sapientia testudini cedit, that snailes were in Sparta, as Oxen were in Rome, or Owles in Athens,Iul. pollux. lib. 9. de verum vo. and all cryed in one voice, Ius in armis.

Wee had also Bulls in times past in England,Bulles sometimes in Englande. that so cryed, Ius in armis, to burne, to kill, and to destroy, which Simon Magus the Roman sent to shed as much bloud in England, as Manasses did in Iuda.

For which bloud, the Lord did send Latrunculos Chaldeorum Moab, & Ammon to destroy Iuda,
and wee thanke God, and say with Ieremie, mirum quod non consumpti fuissemus, and againe say with the Prophet Dauid, that our watching had beene in vaine, (from Spaniards and others) Nisi dominus Ciuitatem, custodijsset, and againe with Isa, say if God had not seured his Church, and the remnant of his people, we should haue beene destroyed like Sodom and Gomorrha.
But now the Image of fortune,Plut in Coroli. spake twise to the Matrons of Rome, giuing them great thanks, saying, Recte me Matrone vidistis, and at another said Rite mihi dedicastis matrone.

The Image of Siluanus, was heard out of the wood Arsia, crying aloud, vno plus Hetrussicadent, And the Image of Ceres at Myletum, at which time Alexander besieged Miletum, and tooke it, and for that his soldiers spoyled, and burned the Temple of Ceres, Lactan. instit. lib. 2. cap. 8. the same fire burned Alexanders soldiers, hinc timor nimius, hence grew the feare of Images, to be more then the feare of Alexander.

So is it Historied, that the Images that Aneas brought from Troy to Italie,Dion. lib. deorum lib 1. were first placed in Lauinium, a towne which Aneas builded, but after Aneas death, Ascanius his sonne brought those Images to his City Alba.
but these Images being not contented to bee taken from their first seate, remoued themselues without the hands or helpe of men, from Alba to Lauinium againe, hinc nimius cultus.

But these are dreames and imaginations of superstitious melancholy people so deeply wrought that they thinke to heare what they heare not, and to see what they see not. So Aristotle writes of one that neuer went abroad, but he thought he saw alwayes an Image euer obiect against him.Arist. lib. 3 Meteor. Another perswading himself that he was so light, got yron shoes, least the wind would blow him away. Another got barkes of Trees bound about his middle,Rhodiginus. least he should bend and breake in the middle. I wrot of this in another place.

So strange are these passions of Melancholie, that one held his head vpon his shoulders, imagining that Atlas being wearie,Melancholy Imaginations. would let the Heauens fall vpon his head, and kill him.

Another perswaded himselfe, that hee had no head, but it was cut off: another imagined that his nose was bigger then his whole bodie: and another at his death told his friends, that he was willing to die, but that he feared theeues which lay in ambush in the middle Region, among the Clouds.

So one thought his shoulders and buttockes to be glasse:Cor. Agrip. lib. 1. Occult. Philos. another beleeued, that he was the snuffe of a Candle, full of imaginations and thoughts, these are but few words.

This was the cause why Images were seene, and the crie of Images heard, Hinc nimius timor, too much feare, too much superstitious worshipping,
that one of Camillus souldiors asked the Image of Iuno in Latine, Vis migrare Romani.
Alcanes would shew his skill to make lame Vulcane streight, because hee should not bee called Claudius Deus.
Phidias was like to be stoned of the people,Phidias. for that he made the Image of Minerua in yuorie and not in brasse, to continue long.
Appelles mused how he might diminish the mole on Venus cheeke.Appelles. Xeuxes how he might make lesse the staine on Helens face.

Euphranor after he had shewed his greatest cunning in limning and setting 12. Gods in Athens,Euphranor. Val. Max. lib. 8. cap. 2. he imagined to make such an Image to Neptune, as should farre excell the Image of Iupiter.

Many Images were made in Greece, some like Mares, that Horses neyed vpō them:Aeli. ver. hist. 2. some like bitches, that dogs followed them: and some made in brasse, like Kine, that Buls lowed vpon them: and some like women, that some yong men fel in loue, that Homer thought good to banish such Painters out of Greece.

What should I speake of Romulus Scepter, of the Image of Seru. Tullius, and of the Image of Claudia the Vestall Virgine, who though the three Temples were burned with fire to the earth, yet the fire could not approach to these Images and Scepter.

Such terrour and feare were of Images in all Countries, that for the taking of a tyle-stone from
the Temple of Iuno by Fulv. Flaccus, hee and his two sonnes died for it:Liv. 42 which thing so frighted the Senators, that they sent the tyle-stone backe again to Iunoes Temple.

The like punishment Qu. Pleminius had for the spoyling of Proserpinaes Temple,Iunoes teeth. so that king Masinissa being presented with certaine yuorie teeth, which came from Melita, vnderstanding they were Iunoes teeth, with much feare excused himselfe, and sent them backe againe, least the goddesse Iuno would be offended with him, as shee was with Flaccus. The feare of Images.
The feare of Images was in many Countries, that neyther Religion nor Lawes were made, vnles they were authorised by Images, and permitted by Augurers.Plut. Mirrors.

As in Creete King Minos was wont euery ninth yeare to climbe a high rocke, and there to stay a while, as though he were that while instructed by supiter, with what Religion and Lawes he should rule the people of Creete.

And for that these Kings would obserue their Religion and Lawes,Val. Max. de. Relig. cap. 3 by their Gods thus authorized, Cne. Calpurnius, in his time, beeing Consull, by the consent of the Senatours made a Decree, That all Philosophers and Chaldaean Astrologers should bee banished out of Rome and Italie,Philosophes banished from Rome. within tenne dayes, least they should deceiue the people with Philosophie and Astronomie.

Egipt the Mother of all superstition, which carried their Gods before them in their Ensignes,The house of Iuda, & Israel, compared to two Harlots. Eze. 23. as chiefe Capraines; with her two daughters Athens, and Rome, were euer accused with the superstition (some time) of Hierusalem and Samaria, which the Prophet calles Aholah and Aholibah: two common harlots that defiled themselues with the Idolatrie of the Assirians, and the Babilonians, and the Caldeans.

In Egipt the Iewes were taught to say to Aron, fac nobis Deos, make vs Gods to goe before vs;Horses, Dog • , and Cats burned. so that in Rome they buried Horses, in Greece Dogges, in Egipt Cates, Crocodiles, and many other such Foules, and Beastes, and that by such men as were Emperours and Kinges.

Alexander the great,Alex. ab Alexandro Lib. 6. cap. 19. buried his horse Bucephalus in Bucephalia: Comodus an Emperour of Rome buried his horse Prasinus, in no base place in Rome, but in Vaticano: and King Merthes made rich Tombes for his Crowes, Cats and Crocodiles, in palude myridis in Egipt.

I wish it were so amongst Christians (that should feare that cursed sentence:Deut. 27. Cursed bee they that serue Idoles and Images) that they would also bury their Images, as these Heathen Princes haue buried their beastes; or as Iacob did Rahels Image; burne them as Iosias did in Hierusalem, and threw the ashes into Cedron.

Sometime Pope Adrian in Rome, Pope Adrian. Gen. 35. would haue done (as Iacob and Iosias did in Israel) destroy
all Idols and Images throughout Rome and all Italie: Hiefield, cap. 7. de terra. calls his Cardinalls and Cleargie to a Synod, where this whole purpose was opened; that many secrets done by the Popes and Cardinalls, were reuealed by these Images per clandestinus intermatros?

One of his Cardinalls said, Holy Father, if you burie these Images as Iacob did,4. Reg. 23. some will seeke them out as Laban did: if you burne them as Iosias did, and throwe the ashes into Tiber, the wind will so scatter the ashes, that they will increase to as many Images, as the Serpents teeth of Medea did to armed men.
In the time of Achab and Manasses, 4. Reg. 16. Israel was full of Idolarie, nothing but Idolatria sortilegia & homicidia, the Altar and the gods of Damascus.

In the time of Amasias the gods of Edome: The gods of Edom. in the time of Achas, not onely the gods of Damascus, the gods of Edome, but also the gods of Syria, 2. Paralip. 18. for Achas said; Dij regum Syriae auxiliantur eis, I will worship and serue them.
So that Images in Israel, were as much honoured and worshipped as amongst the Greekes and the Romans; qui quaerebant Deum inter deos, that sought out God amongst their Images.

King Asa did not so, he destroyed their Idols and their groues in the land of Iuda. 3 Reg. 15. Iosephat ouerthrew their gods and their Altares in Mount Sinay.4. Reg. 18. Ezechias purged the Temple of Ierusalem of their idolatrous reliques, and brake the brasen Serpent into powder.

The Poet faines,Mae tamorph. that the three fatall Ladies of destinie were appointed Scribes and Secretaries vnto Iupiter, to write his lawes and decrees in brasen Tables, which the Heathens did more reuerence and esteeme then the Iewes did the Table in Mount Sinai, written by the finger of God,Exod. 20. and there giuen to Moses to instruct the children of Israel.
Amongst the Ephesians, The Image of Diana. the maiestie of the great goddesse Diana, whose Image came downe from heauen was great, and so great, that Paul escaped narrowly from them aliue.

The Image of Moloch in Tophet in the Valie of Hinuon, Moloch. 4. Reg. 23 where they offered their sonnes and daughters, in sacrifice to their god Moloch, where not onlie the King of Moab, offered his eldest sonne, that should raigne King after him:4 Reg. 16. but Ahaz, King of Iuda, did offer his sonne through fire.

At the spoyle of Rhodes, the Citizens requested nothing, neither wealth, nor treasure at Cassius hand, but this, ne a cunctis Deorum simulacris spoliarentur. That he would not take their gods away altogether. So did Laban expostulate with Iacob for his gods, and so did Micheas runne after the Tribe of Dan, for his Image: and, so many runne to Rome, to Hispaine after Images, and some keepe their Images close in Great Britaine.
